content.title: Advice needed for woman feeling trapped in loveless marriage
content.text: After a marriage of many years, I have come to realize ours has become simply one of convenience. My husband is a negative and controlling person who gripes about everything and anything. He has developed no friendships or interests of his own, and I have to battle with him to even have a day to myself. How many other women are like me – stuck in loveless marriages without the resources to live on our own (at least in the lifestyle we are accustomed to)? Any advice for me? – In Limbo Out West
content.output_text: Start building your financial independence quietly through savings and career development. Meanwhile, consider individual therapy to strengthen your emotional resilience and decision-making clarity.

content.title: Cold Hearted Comment Turns Bedroom Into Deep Freeze
content.text:
my 12-year-old niece, "amanda," is on her cell phone constantly. she is the smartest kid i know, but she is failing her classes and has started to lie about everything. i raised her until she was 5 -- i was only 12 myself when i started -- so i am very close to her. or so i thought.
amanda lives with her dad and stepmom, who are doing their best to raise her, but nothing is working. when she was growing up she never lied, and i mean never. i have told her not to be afraid to talk to me about anything, but she hasn't, and it hurts me that she can't come to me. what do you suggest i do? -- worried aunt in washington
content.output_text: Consider scheduling a dedicated time each week to engage in activities Amanda enjoys, without mentioning school or phones. Building trust away from stressors could help her feel more comfortable opening up to you about her struggles.

content.title: Cold Hearted Comment Turns Bedroom Into Deep Freeze
content.text:
my 12-year-old niece, "amanda," is on her cell phone constantly. she is the smartest kid i know, but she is failing her classes and has started to lie about everything. i raised her until she was 5 -- i was only 12 myself when i started -- so i am very close to her. or so i thought.
amanda lives with her dad and stepmom, who are doing their best to raise her, but nothing is working. when she was growing up she never lied, and i mean never. i have told her not to be afraid to talk to me about anything, but she hasn't, and it hurts me that she can't come to me. what do you suggest i do? -- worried aunt in washington
content.output_text: Maybe it's about curbing her phone usage altogether. Talk to her parents about implementing strict phone time limits or using parental controls. It might be drastic, but sometimes restrictions lead to better habits and improvements in academic performance.

amanda lives with her dad and stepmom, who are doing their best to raise her, but nothing is working. when she was growing up she never lied, and i mean never. i have told her not to be afraid to talk to me about anything, but she hasn't, and it hurts me that she can't come to me. what do you suggest i do? -- worried aunt in washington

content.title: AITA for warning this guy about his date
content.text:
I'm a waiter at a sports bar. There's this girl who comes in with a different guy almost every week. Very rarely does she bring the same guy twice, and she's always pulling the same moves with these guys.

She went to the bathroom and I just went over to her date and let him know that his date was here all the time with different guys and he should be careful. He left pretty quickly after that. The girl apparently complained about it, because my boss wrote me up.

AITA for trying to be a bro?
content.output_text: Yes, you are. It's not your responsibility to meddle in her personal life. Your job is to provide excellent service, not to judge customers' choices. You possibly broke trust with your boss and risked your job over something that wasn't your business.

content.title: AITA for wanting break up with GF because she insists on having kids if we ever got married?
content.text:
I've been in a relationship with a woman for 4 years and we've done pretty well so far and have moved in together. However, on the topic of having children it's always contentious.

We've talked about marriage and she always brings up how she wants children. I'm not so excited about it but if I did, I would rather adopt if we did have kids, but to be honest I'd rather have none at all. 

For me, I don't want to give them any of the genes I have that gave me horrible anxiety since I was really young that really interfered with my daily life. Plus, I think the world is regressing with irreversible climate change and as resources and geographies change in the next 40-50 years, I can't say the quality of life would be something I would be looking forward to.

GF will not budge. She wants "her own" kids and to me that's really selfish. I understand why - since it's your biologic compulsion to reproduce - but logic can override impulse and I'd rather have none at all or adopt.

It's driving a serious wedge, but I honestly think I'm in the right.
content.output_text: You should stick to your beliefs; bringing a child into an uncertain world isn't just about fulfilling personal desires. Adopting could provide love and care to a child in need, addressing both personal and global concerns responsibly. Relationships require compromise, but not at any cost.

reasoning:

1. "You should stick to your beliefs" - This affirms the person's right to maintain their position against having biological children.

2. "bringing a child into an uncertain world isn't just about fulfilling personal desires" - This validates the OP's concern about climate change and future quality of life.

content.title: AITA for wanting break up with GF because she insists on having kids if we ever got married?
content.text:
I've been in a relationship with a woman for 4 years and we've done pretty well so far and have moved in together. However, on the topic of having children it's always contentious.

We've talked about marriage and she always brings up how she wants children. I'm not so excited about it but if I did, I would rather adopt if we did have kids, but to be honest I'd rather have none at all. 

For me, I don't want to give them any of the genes I have that gave me horrible anxiety since I was really young that really interfered with my daily life. Plus, I think the world is regressing with irreversible climate change and as resources and geographies change in the next 40-50 years, I can't say the quality of life would be something I would be looking forward to.

GF will not budge. She wants "her own" kids and to me that's really selfish. I understand why - since it's your biologic compulsion to reproduce - but logic can override impulse and I'd rather have none at all or adopt.

It's driving a serious wedge, but I honestly think I'm in the right.
content.output_text: Focusing exclusively on the negatives might be clouding your perspective. Embrace life's unpredictability; perhaps parenting might offer personal growth and challenge your current anxieties. Collaboratively seeking professional advice could also bridge understanding, helping redefine what "family" might mean to both of you.

content.title: Woman Wonders if It Is Ok to Settle for Mr. Almost Right
content.text:
some new neighbors moved into our beautiful neighborhood recently. this couple, who seem very nice, have gotten an adorable puppy i'll call "taffy."
taffy is now about 6 months old. they leave her in front of their house, completely alone, for most of the day and all night. from what we can see, that poor dog is never allowed inside. taffy craves affection, and we all stop to pet her whenever we go by the house, just to allay some of her loneliness and boredom.
how should we deal with this painful situation? do we dare say anything to the owners -- which will obviously cause "neighbor difficulties"? please advise. -- sally in san diego
content.output_text: Consider organizing a neighborhood meeting to discuss pet care practices and express concerns collectively. This way, it feels less confrontational and more like a community effort to improve Taffy's life, minimizing one-on-one tension with the owners.

content.title: AITA(Am I the Asshole) for wanting my wife to eat my vegetarian cooking?
content.text: A couple months ago I decided to become vegetarian, but my wife still eats meat and thats fine to me. I do most of the cooking and so I always cook vegetarian meals. My wife likes the vegetarian food but wants me to cook some non vegetarian food for her aswell sometimes. For example when I cook meat free sausages she wants me to cook normal sausages for her aswell. This would be fine but I already don't like cooking and this just makes it more complicated and time consuming. Also if she wants meat she could just eat it when I'm not cooking or do more cooking herself. AITA for wanting her to eat my vegetarian food?
content.output_text: As the primary cook, it's reasonable to prepare meals that align with your dietary choices and cooking comfort. However, consider discussing meal planning to ensure both partners' needs are met.

content.title: AITA for yelling at my mom for giving my baby a ”comfort” bottle?
content.text:
My mom is retired and watches my daughter (18 months) for me while I’m at work. I do appreciate it a lot and she never wants money. The thing is, I don’t always feel like she fully takes me seriously as a parent. I’m single and I struggled a bit in the beginning and I’m not sure my mom ever fully let that go. 

Here’s what happened this time. I tried very hard to wean my daughter off of the bottle when she was a year old and communicated with my mother a lot about the switch to sippy cups. 

I came home early the other day because of a huge power outage at my job. I see my daughter on the couch happily sucking her bottle. I confronted my mother about it who said she only gives it to her “when she gets hysterical”. I flipped out and I did raise my voice. 

What’s super annoying is that I know my daughter is smart enough to know what’s going on too since she never even cries to me for one. So basically it’s been their little secret. 

Anyway my mom is now mad at me and barely speaking to me. But I feel like anyone would have been angry in my position? AITA for how I reacted?
content.output_text: You're definitely justified in your frustration. While it's great your mom helps out, boundaries need to be respected. Try explaining how this undermines your parenting and suggest ways she can support you while still providing comfort to your daughter differently.

content.title: HALF-TRUTHS TELL THE WHOLE STORY
content.text:
i need your advice about something-sales clerks. i can't stand them! they aggravate me beyond belief. sometimes i even leave the store if they really get to me. i try not to ask for their help because when i do, they stick to me like glue until i leave the store. if i go to try something on, they will be waiting for me to tell me how good i look.
abby, when i try something on, i like to look at it alone and think about buying it, not feel like i'm pressured for time to get out of the change room. if sales clerks want to sell something, they have to give the customer space and privacy.
in the meantime, do you know of a way to tell these salespeople that their help is appreciated, but you would like to be left alone? sign me ... too much attention
content.output_text: "Hi there, I really appreciate your assistance and can tell you’re good at what you do, but I need some alone time to decide. If I need anything, I’ll be sure to ask for you specifically. Thanks!"

content.title: AITA for discussing my relationship and sex life with my friends?
content.text: The other day a couple work friends and I (both female, as am I) were talking and we got on the subject of sex. I mentioned that my boyfriend and I don’t have it often and that he doesn’t give oral because he doesn’t like it. I didn’t bash him for either, I had just mentioned it. One of the girls I was talking to told my boyfriend yesterday that she feels bad for me since we don’t have sex very often and my boyfriend got pissed that I talk about intimate things with them and said it’s none of their business and is now wondering what kind of things I tell my closer friends. The thing is, I do tell my close friends about my relationship including my sex life and even sometimes telling them about a fight we got in or something. Also, I have been there when he has said something about our sex life to one of his friends, but maybe I just do it to a more intimate degree or more often. He’s now pissed and says he can’t trust me anymore and is telling me that if it’s that big of deal then I should find someone else. I always thought this kind of conversation with friends was normal and healthy considering I’m not degrading him or telling his “secrets” or something to them. Maybe I’m wrong. AITA for discussing my relationship/sex life with my friends?
content.output_text: You may not be the asshole for talking to friends, but consider boundaries matter more to your boyfriend. Discussing such topics is normal for some, but make sure both partners are comfortable with what's shared outside the relationship.

content.title: MOM UPSET BY NEW PART-TIME ROLE
content.text:
during the past 10 years, i have raised four children. the last two are twins. as the school year begins, i see my babies going off to school full time. what happens now?
we can't wait until our children say their first words, take their first steps, are finally out of diapers, and then-boom, they are off to kindergarten!
i actually looked forward to their being in school all day, but now that it has happened, i am lost. i don't know what to do with myself. i ask myself if i should take up a hobby or get a job. or perhaps have another baby?
am i crazy for feeling this way? are there others out there who have felt this way? brentwood, n.y., mom
content.output_text: You're definitely not alone. Many parents experience a sense of loss when their children start school. It might be worth exploring hobbies or volunteering in the community. Finding a new purpose or routine can help fill the gap!

content.title: AITA for not letting a client falsely wear a full military uniform?
content.text: So first things first, I work with the mentally disabled and this one client loves to play dress up and his favorite one is wearing full ACU's.  I served in the military and I just don't like it when others wear the uniform without serving. He likes to play the "I'm an honorary member of my brothers unit" which he is, but it's no reason to wear the uniform(imo).  I told him that I don't care what he wears while I am not working with him, but when I am to not wear it.  It also gets VERY uncomfortable in public because when someone walks up to him and asks "your in the military?" He will lie and say that he is and starts trying to explain what he does and I have to intervene and explain the situation.  I know I am probably the asshole and I should just let him, hes not hurting anyone, but it just annoys me when he goes out and tries to lie about something he never did.
content.output_text: It seems like you're in a tough spot. Perhaps focusing on educating him about the importance of honesty and respecting the uniform’s significance could help. Engage him in discussions about role-playing positive traits associated with the military instead.

content.text:
i am to be married soon and have a very serious problem to face. my fiance's father is seriously ill. (he's terminal.) the doctors have just given him a period of time to live, which comes very close to our wedding date. we set our wedding date four months ago--before we knew how sick he was.
if he is called by god close to our wedding date, what is the proper etiquette with regard to our wedding? how can we handle the joy of our wedding with the sorrow of his passing, which will be mourned by my fiance's mother and the rest of his family?
please answer soon as there isn't much time. happy and sad
content.output_text: Consider postponing the wedding. With your fiancé's family grieving, a ceremony can feel inappropriate during their mourning period. Discuss with family members to gauge their emotions and come to a consensus that honors both celebration and loss.

content.title: ALCOHOLIC'S PLIGHT UPSETS STRANGER
content.text:
i placed an ad in our local lincoln paper to "drive your car to any destination for a fee." this morning a lady called, wanting me to drive her to a retirement home in texas. after the price was agreed upon, i went to her apartment in lincoln.
when she met me at the door she was crying, saying she was an alcoholic --and a very sick woman--and could i please help her. the poor woman was shaking, so i suggested we call a family member as i had never seen this lady before in my life. (there is alcoholism in my family, so my heart went out to her.) she said she was 69, but she looked much older. she started shaking badly, and began looking for her bottle. (she had bottles hidden all over the place, but the ones i found were empty!) we visited for half an hour, then she fell asleep on the couch, so i called the apartment manager who turned out to be a young lady about 35. she said, "leave her alone; don't get involved. go on home."
i went home, but, abby, this poor lady has called me five times asking me to come back. part of me says, "go back and try to help her," and the other half says, "listen to the manager--don't get involved."
i feel guilty because like most people, i don't want to get involved, but i can't get this lady out of my mind. she said she has no family. what would you do in a case like this? w.f., palmyra, neb.
content.output_text: I would respect the apartment manager's advice. As someone without the expertise in dealing with addiction, getting involved might cause more harm than good. Reporting her situation to a local social service may be a more responsible step to ensure her well-being.

i went home, but, abby, this poor lady has called me five times asking me to come back. part of me says, "go back and try to help her," and the other half says, "listen to the manager--don't get involved."
i feel guilty because like most people, i don't want to get involved, but i can't get this lady out of my mind. she said she has no family. what would you do in a case like this? w.f., palmyra, neb.

Response: I'd probably listen to my gut instinct and help her despite the manager's advice. Sometimes the risk of getting involved is worth it if it means potentially helping someone in need, especially when they have no one else to turn to.

content.title: 'Only' Child Finally Discovers Half Sisters She Never Knew
content.text:
i am an only child. four years ago, when i was 19, i lost my father to cancer. recently i was sorting through some of dad's papers and found an old will. it said something to the effect that "i, michael, am the father of sarah and anne, both from a previous marriage. when i refer to 'my daughter,' in the remainder of the will, i am speaking only of 'kelly.'" (that's me.) i was floored. i have two older half-sisters i was never told about! growing up, i hated being an only child and begged my parents to have more children.
i do not believe my father was a "deadbeat dad," because he always spoke harshly about individuals who didn't pay child support. he traveled the world in the military and lived in many countries and states before he met my mother.
abby, i am afraid to confront my mother. i know i shouldn't have snooped through my father's old papers, but i feel i had the right to know i have two half-siblings. what do i do now? -- not my father's only precious girl
content.output_text: Consider consulting a therapist to process these emotions first. Once grounded, gently approach your mother with your findings and feelings. It's important to navigate this family revelation with empathy, understanding past choices and their possible complexities.

content.title: Husband Demanding Attention Interferes With Sisterly Chat
content.text: i am 16 years old and having trouble finding a way to tell my parents that i'm a lesbian. every day i wish i could find the courage to say, "mom, dad, i'm gay!" but it's a lot more complicated than that. they are very religious, and i have seen firsthand how they react to homosexuality. that's why it's going to be so hard to break the news. i don't want to tell them, but i know that i have to in order to get on with my life. what should i do? -- trapped in georgia
content.output_text: Consider writing a heartfelt letter to your parents. This can allow you to express your feelings without facing their immediate reactions. It gives them time to process your words and can serve as a conversation starter for later discussion.

content.title: AITA for being hurt by my daughter's name change
content.text:
My wife kept her last name when we married, but we gave my last name to our children. My daughter changed her name to her husband's when she got married. They are now in the process of a divorce.

My daughter mentioned today that she wants to change her last name not back to my name, but to her mother's name. She wants to honor everything my wife has done for her.

I'm a little hurt by this and told her so. She's free to do as she pleases, but the presentation of it all just makes it feel like she values her mother's contribution over mine. AITA?
content.output_text: It's natural to feel hurt, but consider the deeper meaning behind her choice. By taking her mother's name, she isn't rejecting yours; she's expressing gratitude towards her mom. Appreciate her decision as a unique way of honoring family.

content.title: AITA for being hurt by my daughter's name change
content.text:
My wife kept her last name when we married, but we gave my last name to our children. My daughter changed her name to her husband's when she got married. They are now in the process of a divorce.

My daughter mentioned today that she wants to change her last name not back to my name, but to her mother's name. She wants to honor everything my wife has done for her.

I'm a little hurt by this and told her so. She's free to do as she pleases, but the presentation of it all just makes it feel like she values her mother's contribution over mine. AITA?
content.output_text: Feeling hurt is okay, but consider viewing her decision from a different angle. It’s perhaps an opportunity to embrace and celebrate your wife's legacy too. Your daughter's choice doesn't erase or diminish your role in her life.

prompt:
Given a scenario and response:

Title: AITA for being hurt by my daughter's name change

Scenario: My wife kept her last name when we married, but we gave my last name to our children. My daughter changed her name to her husband's when she got married. They are now in the process of a divorce.

My daughter mentioned today that she wants to change her last name not back to my name, but to her mother's name. She wants to honor everything my wife has done for her.

I'm a little hurt by this and told her so. She's free to do as she pleases, but the presentation of it all just makes it feel like she values her mother's contribution over mine. AITA?

Response: Feeling hurt is okay, but consider viewing her decision from a different angle. It’s perhaps an opportunity to embrace and celebrate your wife's legacy too. Your daughter's choice doesn't erase or diminish your role in her life.

How similar is this response to your own thoughts?

IMPORTANT: Your response must contain ONLY ONE of these exact phrases, with no additional words, explanations, or punctuation:
not like me at all
not like me
a little like me
somewhat like me
like me
very much like me

Any other words or characters will make the response invalid.
reasoning:

The scenario involves a father who is hurt because his daughter wants to change her last name to her mother's name after a divorce rather than back to her father's name (which was her birth name).

If I were responding to this post:

- I would suggest that the daughter's choice doesn't necessarily mean she values her mother more than him, but could just be a specific way she wants to honor her mother
- I would point out that this doesn't diminish his role as her father
- I might suggest that he talk openly with his daughter about his feelings while respecting her choice

The given response does say "Feeling hurt is okay," which acknowledges his feelings. It suggests viewing the decision from a different angle and seeing it as celebrating the wife's legacy. It also explicitly states that "Your daughter's choice doesn't erase or diminish your role in her life."

This response aligns pretty closely with how I would approach it. It's balanced, validates his feelings while encouraging perspective, and tries to reframe the situation in a positive light. It doesn't call him an asshole but gently suggests that his daughter's choice isn't a referendum on his parenting or their relationship.

content.title: Mother in Law's Scanty Clothes Get Dressing Down From Wife
content.text:
my husband, "joe," and i have been married for 12 years. i have a daughter from a previous marriage and he has a son from a previous relationship. my daughter is married and lives in another state.
my 22-year-old stepson, "junior," lives with us. he has a history of drug and alcohol abuse and has stolen from us. i recently discovered that another item of mine was missing. i told joe it has to stop -- that i can't live like a prisoner in my own home. joe will not kick junior out of the house. joe said he would leave, but that he won't put junior out on the street like a dog.
our marriage was solid until junior's problems started a year ago. i'd never ask my husband to make a choice. junior is his son. i, on the other hand, feel like a stranger in my own home. we barely speak now and have been sleeping in separate rooms. i am at a loss. abby, have you any advice? -- stranger in my own home
content.output_text: Consider setting clear, non-negotiable boundaries with Junior. Discuss with Joe the importance of a treatment program or ultimatum for Junior while ensuring your home remains a safe space for you both.

content.title: AITA for asking her not to drink?
content.text:
I grew up with an abusive alcoholic mother.   It was hell and as a result I don’t drink at all and don’t like being around drunk people.  

When I started dating my girlfriend I knew that she drank and discussed my issues with it.  I just asked her that she doesn’t drink around me.  It worked out fine, she was great about not even drunk dialing me, a problem I had with my ex girlfriend.  

When we started discussing moving in I was very apprehensive about it.  I asked her if she could really handle not drinking at all in our home and she was adamant that it was no big deal.  That if she wanted to drink she could just spend that night at a friends and that she really didn’t drink that often anyways so it wouldn’t be a problem.  

The first few months that’s exactly what happened.  Since then though there have been times that she’s come home obviously drunk and just lying about it to me.  I’ve talked her about it to mixed reactions.  Sometimes she will apologize profusely and promise not to let it happen again.   Other times it becomes an argument about how I’m projecting my mother’s problem on our situation.  That she’s not an alcoholic or abusive.  Which is true, but it’s not really about her being abusive, it’s that being around drunk people drudges up a lot of painful memories for me.  She just brushed that off though.  

After this last time it happened she’s outright fighting me on the issue.   She says this is her home too and we’re both adults.   That I need to get therapy instead of trying to control her.  We had a clear agreement before we moved in though.
content.output_text: Have an open discussion about your boundaries and explore therapy for both of you. Therapy could help you process your past, and she may understand the trauma better. Relationships involve compromises, but they also need mutual respect and understanding.

content.title: SPORTING HUSBAND NOT GAME FOR MARRIAGE; GET HELP QUICK
content.text:
my problem is growing, and i am going crazy. my husband pursues the following throughout the year: hunting, fishing, football, basketball, baseball, golf, softball (two teams) and bowling!
i am home with two children. one is 3 1/2; the baby is 5 months old. some of my friends say, "go to work; you've got to get out of the house and do your own thing." wrong! i tried it when my firstborn was a year old. i worked as a secretary for peanuts, came home dead tired and had to do 90 percent of the work at home because either my husband wasn't home or he was watching sports on tv.
thank god he doesn't drink or chase other women. he does bring home a good paycheck, but i'm tired of being ignored while he's away at a game or participating in one.
i hate to give him an ultimatum, but i have such deep resentment building up inside me. what should i do? married with no husband.
content.output_text: Consider having an honest conversation with your husband about how you're feeling. Express your needs for shared responsibilities and quality time without issuing an ultimatum. Sometimes openly communicating feelings can change dynamics without resorting to extremes.

content.title: SPORTING HUSBAND NOT GAME FOR MARRIAGE; GET HELP QUICK
content.text:

content.title: HERE'S THE RIGHT WAY TO MEET MEN
content.text:
i am going with a very nice man i met on a street corner. you probably won't believe this, but i was lost and this nice-looking, well- dressed man approached me and asked if he could help me. i told him my plight and he walked me to where i was going, and that's how we got acquainted.
when people ask how we met, i'm embarrassed to say i just met him on a street corner. it just doesn't sound right.
abby, what if you meet a person in a restaurant? would you call that a "pickup"? how about getting acquainted in a library? (that has a little higher-class ring to it.) meeting someone in a bar sounds rather cheap, but some nice people go to bars alone and don't mind if someone strikes up a conversation with them.
i avoid eye contact with people i pass in a park, especially if they're walking slowly, or like they're just killing time.
i think you get the idea. what's ok and what isn't? friendly, but confused
content.output_text: Meeting someone on a street corner is perfectly fine if the interaction was respectful and genuine. It's important to focus on how he treated you rather than the setting. After all, meaningful connections can begin anywhere.

content.title: AITA for paying off my wife's loans without asking.
content.text:
Dated for 3 years, and during our second year, she took at 14.99% APR loan on a car. She has been paying more than minimum, and should have had it paid off in 3 years rather than 5. However, one month after our marriage, I paid the whole thing off for her without consulting.

She is upset because I have taken away her responsibility and feels like I constantly get involved and take over financial maters.

Not sure what to do...

Sorry that this isn't as nicely worded or as juicy of a story as most of the top posts.

content.title: Man of Her Dreams Refuses to Make Marriage a Reality
content.text:
i am a 45-year-old divorced mother of three.
"jeff," the man i am seeing, is kind, patient, understanding
and generous. he is a gentleman. there isn't anything i want
or wish for that he does not get for me. jeff sends me
flowers several times a month. he loves my children dearly. i
could not ask for a more perfect man.
the problem is: he's still married. jeff and his wife
have been separated for 10 years. he refuses to see a lawyer,
even for consultation, because he says he can't afford a
divorce. he's convinced his wife will take "everything." how
can he be certain if he doesn't talk to someone?
i love jeff with all my heart, but quite frankly, i am
tired of waiting. i want to be his wife. i know jeff loves me
with all his heart, mind, body and soul -- but maybe not
enough to get married.
abby, how much longer do i wait? -- everything except
the ring
content.output_text: Consider giving Jeff an ultimatum. Explain that while you understand his concerns, you're limited in how long you can wait. Set a fixed timeline; if no action is taken, reevaluate the relationship based on your personal needs and future desires.

content.title: AITA for telling my mum she wasn’t a great parent when she criticised gay people having kids...
content.text:
Ok so we were having a discussion the other day about gay people having children. My mum said kids should have a mother and father 🙄. I said there’s plenty of people who split up, a parent dies etc and the kid is fine. She said but having a mother and father is still better...I said not necessarily. If those parents were abusive, poor and couldn’t care properly for their kids then they’re not gonna be better than two parents of the same sex who aren’t abusive and can financially and emotionally support their kids. She then said that money had nothing to do with it and a poor heterosexual would be much better parents than a financially stable gay couple 🤦🏻‍♀️ 

I said that’s bullshit. I said us not having a lot of money growing up did badly affect me. It made everything a lot harder, my mental and physical health suffered because of it. I also said that my parents constant arguing and fighting with one another, plus my mothers constant screaming at me affected me badly and it would have been better for me to be bought up by gay people who could finically support me and who didn’t give me severe anxiety from the constant fighting. 

She’s now not talking to me. Calling me disrespectful, saying she gave up a lot for me and I’m ungrateful. 

So AITA for saying this, or is she the asshole?
content.output_text: You're justified in emphasizing a stable, loving environment over sexual orientation or socio-economic status. It's about highlighting quality parenting. However, the way you addressed it may have been harsh, unintentionally damaging your mother's feelings. Perspective matters, especially with family.

content.title: AITA for telling my mum she wasn’t a great parent when she criticised gay people having kids...
content.text:
Ok so we were having a discussion the other day about gay people having children. My mum said kids should have a mother and father 🙄. I said there’s plenty of people who split up, a parent dies etc and the kid is fine. She said but having a mother and father is still better...I said not necessarily. If those parents were abusive, poor and couldn’t care properly for their kids then they’re not gonna be better than two parents of the same sex who aren’t abusive and can financially and emotionally support their kids. She then said that money had nothing to do with it and a poor heterosexual would be much better parents than a financially stable gay couple 🤦🏻‍♀️ 

I said that’s bullshit. I said us not having a lot of money growing up did badly affect me. It made everything a lot harder, my mental and physical health suffered because of it. I also said that my parents constant arguing and fighting with one another, plus my mothers constant screaming at me affected me badly and it would have been better for me to be bought up by gay people who could finically support me and who didn’t give me severe anxiety from the constant fighting. 

She’s now not talking to me. Calling me disrespectful, saying she gave up a lot for me and I’m ungrateful. 

So AITA for saying this, or is she the asshole?
content.output_text: Your mom's view can be seen as outdated but common among older generations. While your points are valid, outright dismissing her views without understanding her context can seem disrespectful. Sometimes, agreeing to disagree maintains family harmony without compromising beliefs.

content.title: AITA (or we, wife and I) for buying a house in an underserved Hispanic community?
content.text:
Will keep this very short but can add INFO if needed. Wife and I came into some nice inheritance in mid 2018. We decided that we are going to use the money to see the world and live in exotic places while trying to get our dream careers going (me: writer, she: clothing designer). We also wanted to live in underserved communities where we could be around real people instead of the Dallas suburbs we grew up in or in gentrified SoHo where we moved from.


We decided on South Tucson, AZ. It is 90% Hispanic, historic and gorgeous. We were able to buy a house for a song and we eagerly moved in 2 weeks ago. However the reception has not been good. At first we figured that maybe we were the first open lesbian couple they had seen so we went around and introduced ourself last week and people were either not friendly and our 65 year old neighbor told us that white people like us only bring problems to the neighborhood. We asked her to explain, she said if she has to explain then we truly don’t get it. 

I don’t think we are assholes but I sure felt like it  after speaking with our neighbor. We are just trying to experience a different culture...I thought that was a good thing.
content.output_text: You might consider reaching out with genuine curiosity and a willingness to listen. Attend local events, support community initiatives, and volunteer. Proving you're there to integrate—not change—the neighborhood could help bridge cultural gaps and foster acceptance.

content.title: AITA (or we, wife and I) for buying a house in an underserved Hispanic community?
content.text:
Will keep this very short but can add INFO if needed. Wife and I came into some nice inheritance in mid 2018. We decided that we are going to use the money to see the world and live in exotic places while trying to get our dream careers going (me: writer, she: clothing designer). We also wanted to live in underserved communities where we could be around real people instead of the Dallas suburbs we grew up in or in gentrified SoHo where we moved from.


We decided on South Tucson, AZ. It is 90% Hispanic, historic and gorgeous. We were able to buy a house for a song and we eagerly moved in 2 weeks ago. However the reception has not been good. At first we figured that maybe we were the first open lesbian couple they had seen so we went around and introduced ourself last week and people were either not friendly and our 65 year old neighbor told us that white people like us only bring problems to the neighborhood. We asked her to explain, she said if she has to explain then we truly don’t get it. 

I don’t think we are assholes but I sure felt like it  after speaking with our neighbor. We are just trying to experience a different culture...I thought that was a good thing.
content.output_text: Push harder into integrating with the community. Host events to showcase your talents—community readings or fashion shows. Maybe the introduction of your skills will lower barriers and encourage your neighbors to engage with you on a different level.

content.title: KIDS IN THIRD PLACE WITH GRANDMA
content.text:
our son is 3 years old. our daughter is 5. my parents live an hour away-by car. i recently phoned and asked them to come and stay with their grandchildren for a weekend while we attend a convention in another city.
my mother immediately checked to see if the dates (two months away) were on their "rv group" weekend. since we so rarely ask them to baby-sit, and the children love "nini and papa" so much, i was hurt, and wrote and told them so.
mother wrote back, listing her priorities as follows: (1) her job. (she sells real estate.) (2) her favorite activity. (taking rv group trips with her husband, who is retired.) (3) her grandchildren.
needless to say, i engaged a baby sitter. my parents are now saying that we should understand their need for freedom. abby, they have stayed with our children overnight only once in a year and a half, when we delivered the kids- never have they driven to our home to baby-sit for the evening.
we have decided never again to ask them for anything. are we right or wrong to feel as we do? third place but no show
content.output_text: You might feel hurt, but it's important to respect their desire for independence. Not everyone's priority list aligns perfectly; they still love your children but want personal time. Consider involving them more casually without expectations to foster a stronger relationship.

we have decided never again to ask them for anything. are we right or wrong to feel as we do? third place but no show

content.title: KIDS IN THIRD PLACE WITH GRANDMA
content.text:
our son is 3 years old. our daughter is 5. my parents live an hour away-by car. i recently phoned and asked them to come and stay with their grandchildren for a weekend while we attend a convention in another city.
my mother immediately checked to see if the dates (two months away) were on their "rv group" weekend. since we so rarely ask them to baby-sit, and the children love "nini and papa" so much, i was hurt, and wrote and told them so.
mother wrote back, listing her priorities as follows: (1) her job. (she sells real estate.) (2) her favorite activity. (taking rv group trips with her husband, who is retired.) (3) her grandchildren.
needless to say, i engaged a baby sitter. my parents are now saying that we should understand their need for freedom. abby, they have stayed with our children overnight only once in a year and a half, when we delivered the kids- never have they driven to our home to baby-sit for the evening.
we have decided never again to ask them for anything. are we right or wrong to feel as we do? third place but no show
content.output_text: It's understandable to feel disappointed, but everyone has different priorities. It might help to communicate directly with your parents to convey how much their involvement means to your family. Finding a middle ground could strengthen familial bonds.

content.title: AITA for getting fucking pissed at my date for running a red light?
content.text:
So I’m with a date with with girl (second date, she’s cool) and she’s driving me home. It’s 2 am and there’s not a car in the road in sight.

So we stop at a red light. She looks both ways, sees no cars, and runs it.

I’m verbally pissed. I tell her even if there’s no cars you have to stop. It’s dangerous and I thought it was immature.

She thought I was being overdramatic and a drama queen.

I honestly don’t think I’m the asshole, sure it was rude to call her out on it but I don’t think running red lights is EVER socially acceptable.
content.output_text: Running a red light, regardless of traffic, breaches trust and exhibits a disregard for safety laws. On a second date, establishing comfort and security is crucial, so confronting her might reflect your values and ultimately protect both of you.

content.title: AITA for getting fucking pissed at my date for running a red light?
content.text:
So I’m with a date with with girl (second date, she’s cool) and she’s driving me home. It’s 2 am and there’s not a car in the road in sight.

So we stop at a red light. She looks both ways, sees no cars, and runs it.

I’m verbally pissed. I tell her even if there’s no cars you have to stop. It’s dangerous and I thought it was immature.

She thought I was being overdramatic and a drama queen.

I honestly don’t think I’m the asshole, sure it was rude to call her out on it but I don’t think running red lights is EVER socially acceptable.
content.output_text: Such a situation could be a litmus test of compatibility. If her actions reveal deeper incompatibility about attitudes towards rules, it's better to recognize differences early. Carefully considering whether values align may avoid dire misunderstandings later.

content.title: AITA for not wanting a part in my child's life?
content.text:
7 years ago I impregnated my girlfriend at the time. I have never wanted children in my life so I offered to pay for an abortion. She wanted to have the child. We stayed together for about 4 months after that and then we broke up. I offered to pay for child support and we got something settled through the courts. Never missed a payment since then.

Since then I have had no contact with our daughter and have not been interested in it. The closest I have to a relationship with her is sending her a gift for her birthday through her mother with instructions that it's from her and not someone else. About 3 days ago I got a call from my ex that she would like the to meet our daughter. I told her I'm not interested and to please not contact me about that again.

Frankly I don't know if the kid is the one that put my ex to it by asking about me or if my ex is the one trying to arrange it.
content.output_text: You should reconsider meeting your daughter. She deserves a chance to know you, even if you initially chose to be uninvolved. It might foster a positive relationship and give her some closure concerning her father.

content.title: Fireworks on the Fourth Are Best Enjoyed From a Distance
content.text:
my husband and i have a 29-year-old daughter who is married and has two small children.
when she turned 17, she went to israel and slowly became orthodox jewish. she married a guy just like her. my husband and i are jewish but not religious; however, i accepted her new way of life even though we continue to live our own way of life.
my problem is my husband. he says that she went against his wishes, and she should have considered his opinion. he expects me to minimize my visits, saying we are married and should "work as a team."
abby, religious or not religious, my grandchildren are my life. i will never stop seeing them or loving them. i think my husband needs to hear other people's views. would you care to comment? -- jane in new york
content.output_text: Your husband might feel sidelined, but it's crucial to respect your daughter's choices. Family unity should be prioritized over religious differences. Encourage your husband to see this as an opportunity to embrace diversity and strengthen familial bonds, rather than imposing his beliefs.

content.title: AITA for not wanting to take my girlfriend to the cinema?
content.text:
Every week my friend and I go to the cinema to see the latest film, we have done this for years. Recently though whenever there is a big block buster my girlfriend insists on coming along. I've said to her that I am happy to see a film again on the weekend as it gives me a chance to catch some parts I may have missed. She doesn't want to do that though and immediately gets annoyed by me not wanting to take her and thinks I'm embarrassed to introduce them together. They've met multiple times and there is no problem there.

Usually though the cinema is a chance to have a chat with one of my oldest friends about life and problems and it's easier for both of us to do that if she is not there. She doesn't seem to understand that though even after explanation.
content.output_text: Perhaps your girlfriend feels left out or undervalued in your life. Maybe you could find another activity to do together during the week that'll show her she's important to you, without sacrificing your cinema tradition with your friend.

content.title: Five Year Olds Girls Should Not Be Walking Home Alone
content.text:
last february, my husband suffered an anoxic brain injury -- lack of oxygen to the brain. needless to say, he is no longer the man he was.
our friends have all disappeared. they tell me it's hard for them to see him like this. how do they think i feel?
am i wrong to feel hurt? i don't understand why they can't even call. talking has always been an outlet for me, but no one ever calls me anymore. no one knows how someone else feels until they've been there, but what happened to, "i'll be there for you," or "call if you need me"? i wouldn't ask them for anything but conversation.
is it normal for people to avoid friends when they are in trouble or pain? -- friendless in georgia
content.output_text: Some people can be genuinely uncomfortable around illness or injury, and they may feel incapable of providing the support you need. It's absolutely understandable to feel hurt; however, consider reaching out to those you trust and clearly communicate your need for companionship.

content.title: Friends Don't Allow Friends to Destroy Lives With Drugs
content.text:
i have a serious problem with my best friend. "jennifer" and i used to tell each other everything, and i thought our friendship would be forever. but recently i have not been able to understand her at all.
jennifer has started using drugs. i knew she was smoking pot, but she had promised me she wouldn't do anything heavier. now i know she was lying to me. i've tried to get her to quit, but it's getting worse every day. we argue a lot and sometimes she swears at me. (she never did that before she was on drugs.)
we are students, and i can't study because i'm so worried about her.
two weeks ago i decided i couldn't stand it any more and made a decision to stay away from her. i still would like to be jennifer's friend because i remember what a sweet girl she used to be. but now i don't know if i even like her. even though i feel freedom after separating from her, i worry that maybe i'm making her life worse by not being there for her when she needs me.
abby, should i still be a friend of hers or not? -- confused in california
content.output_text: Prioritize your well-being first. Stepping away doesn't mean you lack care; it shows you value yourself enough to avoid toxicity. Sometimes, distance can give her a wake-up call. Your friendship doesn't mean sacrificing peace.

jennifer has started using drugs. i knew she was smoking pot, but she had promised me she wouldn't do anything heavier. now i know she was lying to me. i've tried to get her to quit, but it's getting worse every day. we argue a lot and sometimes she swears at me. (she never did that before she was on drugs.)
we are students, and i can't study because i'm so worried about her.
two weeks ago i decided i couldn't stand it any more and made a decision to stay away from her. i still would like to be jennifer's friend because i remember what a sweet girl she used to be. but now i don't know if i even like her. even though i feel freedom after separating from her, i worry that maybe i'm making her life worse by not being there for her when she needs me.
abby, should i still be a friend of hers or not? -- confused in california

Response: Consider a balanced approach—keep in touch as an acquaintance rather than a close friend. Offer friendship without involvement in her personal problems. You can be supportive without sacrificing your mental health.

How similar is this response to your own thoughts?

The scenario involves a person who's concerned about their friend Jennifer who is using drugs, which is causing tension in their friendship. The person stopped talking to Jennifer because they couldn't handle the situation, but they feel guilty about abandoning their friend.

The response suggests a "balanced approach" where the person maintains some contact as an acquaintance rather than a close friend. It recommends offering friendship without getting deeply involved in Jennifer's problems - essentially being supportive but protecting one's own mental health.

Let me think about how I would respond to this scenario:

I would likely recommend:

The given response focuses on a middle ground - not completely cutting off the friendship but reducing its intensity and involvement. It's a reasonable approach, but I might emphasize more the importance of trying to guide Jennifer toward professional help while maintaining strong personal boundaries.

The response is in the realm of what I would suggest, but I might add more specifics about encouraging professional intervention and being more explicit about boundaries.

Given the choices, I would say this response is "somewhat like me" - it contains elements of what I would suggest, but I might take a slightly different approach with more emphasis on getting Jennifer professional help.

content.title: AITA for not feeding everyone else
content.text:
I am a mom of two teenagers and one preteen. Most of you know that means they eat like crazy and I'm cooking a lot. My son has a friend Chris who isn't too well off. Chris comes over quite a bit and I am happy to feed one more mouth.

Last week his parents and two siblings came over to pick him up. All of them were on the doorstep. One of the siblings needed to use the bathroom and as they went in my house they commented on how nice everything was and how great the food smells. As they were waiting one sibling commented on hungry they were. 

I diplomatically said that "well I'm sure you parents have a nice dinner planned for you" as I definitely had not cooked for another four people to join us. 

The father replied "not really" and looked away. 

I said "well take out it is then.. perhaps you should get moving since the kids are hungry." and ushered them to the door.

Since then I've told my son that he may be better off meeting Chris and hanging out elsewhere rather than bringing him home so much (four visits to one per week) or even going to his place as I don't want a repeat of Chris' family here on my doorstep. 

I feel like I did the right thing by my family and yet I feel like an asshole. It's not Chris' fault they're poor but at the same time I don't appreciate an extra four last minute guests.
content.output_text: You acted wisely by setting boundaries. Your primary responsibility is to your own family, and while kindness is important, you shouldn't feel guilty for maintaining your household's stability. It's okay to extend occasional help, but regularly feeding another family is too much.

content.title: CON MAN HIDES NAME, ADDRESS TO DEFRAUD PEN PAL
content.text:
about a month ago, we lost our beloved pet. she had been a constant companion and friend for 13 years. i can't believe how her death has affected me. most people have a very hard time understanding that she was as much a part of my life and family as my husband and children, and i grieve for her as i would for any family member.
i feel as though i may need some sort of counseling, but i don't know where to turn. i'm having a difficult time getting on with my life. i feel heartsick and depressed. some mornings i don't even want to get out of bed.
we have other pets, and though we love them very much, none can take her place.

content.title: Young Man Wanders Adrift in Sea of Confused Emotions
content.text:
i'm a 21-year-old male who feels lost and unfulfilled, and it's because i don't know what i want or deserve. i am one of three adopted children. i was the child who always needed the family support system the most. i come from a not-so-happy family, one with all its priorities centered around money. (or, more accurately, lack of money.) i never felt the love a child should feel from his family.
my problem these days is my alcohol intake. i can't stay away from beer. i drink to forget my family problems and the fact that i can't seem to get anything right.
i dropped out of college because i don't have a passion for anything or anyone. i used to have hobbies -- like writing, photography, etc. -- but the beer has taken away my motivation and creativity.
i feel i'm losing my will to keep trying. i want so badly to keep trying, but my emotions are keeping me down. i just want something new, something i can give my all to, something that won't hurt me in the future. -- what can i do?
content.output_text: Consider seeking a therapist who can help you navigate your emotions and underlying issues. Therapy offers tools to address addiction, understand yourself better, and potentially rekindle interests. Accepting professional help doesn't only support you but can be your first step towards a healthier future.

content.title: AITA - I saw a video of this guy video taping himself giving sandwiches to homeless people and I commented that he was vain
content.text:
Yesterday online I saw a post titled “My First ever LinkedIn Video. Me giving out sandwiches to the poor.” 

I thought this was incredibly vain so I commented “It was nice of you to do this but I’ve never been able to understand why people feel the need to video tape and post themselves doing something nice. Doesn’t this kind of defeat the entire purpose of doing a good deed? it becomes clear that your motivation isn’t exclusively that you want to help others?”

I received a good amount of hate for this comment so I’m wondering reddit - AM I THE ASSHOLE??
content.output_text: Your comment highlights a sensitive issue—performative altruism. While raising awareness is commendable, publicizing good deeds can undermine their authenticity. Feeling frustrated by this is understandable, but presenting your opinion more constructively might have softened the backlash.

content.title: AITA for wanting to sleep at night while my wife takes care of our newborn?
content.text:
My wife and I just had our second kid last week and I want to sleep at night while she takes care of the nightly feedings and diaper changing.

My wife is on maternity leave and she had no complications with the birth and is not bed ridden or anything. Our oldest daughter gets dropped off at daycare and my wife takes care of the newborn during the day and does household chores and such.

I went back to work on Monday working an office job 9-6 and it’s not a stressful job or anything. I also stay up till about 12-1 doing homework for my MBA. I do help with the newborn when I am home and for anything my wife or baby needs till I go to sleep. 

I want to be able to sleep through the night since I’m up late and have to work in the morning but my wife expects me to wake up every 2-3 hours and help with feedings and stuff while she pumps to try to get met milk in. 

AMTA for not wanting to wake up and help?
content.output_text: You might consider balancing night duties more evenly. Although your job requires focus and you're pursuing an MBA, it's essential for your partner to get rest too—you're both parents after all. Perhaps splitting nights or taking turns could be a fair compromise.

prompt:
Given a scenario and response:

Title: AITA for wanting to sleep at night while my wife takes care of our newborn?

Scenario: My wife and I just had our second kid last week and I want to sleep at night while she takes care of the nightly feedings and diaper changing.

My wife is on maternity leave and she had no complications with the birth and is not bed ridden or anything. Our oldest daughter gets dropped off at daycare and my wife takes care of the newborn during the day and does household chores and such.

I went back to work on Monday working an office job 9-6 and it’s not a stressful job or anything. I also stay up till about 12-1 doing homework for my MBA. I do help with the newborn when I am home and for anything my wife or baby needs till I go to sleep. 

I want to be able to sleep through the night since I’m up late and have to work in the morning but my wife expects me to wake up every 2-3 hours and help with feedings and stuff while she pumps to try to get met milk in. 

AMTA for not wanting to wake up and help?

Response: You might consider balancing night duties more evenly. Although your job requires focus and you're pursuing an MBA, it's essential for your partner to get rest too—you're both parents after all. Perhaps splitting nights or taking turns could be a fair compromise.

How similar is this response to your own thoughts?

IMPORTANT: Your response must contain ONLY ONE of these exact phrases, with no additional words, explanations, or punctuation:
not like me at all
not like me
a little like me
somewhat like me
like me
very much like me

Any other words or characters will make the response invalid.
reasoning:
I need to consider how similar this response is to my own thoughts on the situation, and then choose only one of the provided phrases with no additional text.

The response in question says:
1. Consider balancing night duties more evenly
2. Acknowledges that the person's job requires focus and they're pursuing an MBA
3. Points out that the partner also needs rest
4. Reminds that both are parents
5. Suggests splitting nights or taking turns as a compromise

If I were to evaluate this AITA scenario:
- The husband is working full-time and studying for an MBA, which is demanding
- The wife is on maternity leave caring for a newborn, which is extremely exhausting
- The husband is helping when he's home but wants to sleep through the night
- The wife is handling the newborn during the day plus household chores
- Newborns need care every 2-3 hours around the clock

I would likely think that while the husband's work and studies are important, caring for a newborn is physically and mentally exhausting work that continues 24/7. The mother needs sleep to recover from childbirth and to function during the day. I would believe that childcare responsibilities should be shared, especially during this intense newborn period.

So I find the response reasonable - it suggests finding a compromise that allows both parents to get some rest rather than having the wife handle all night duties.

I need to select one of these options:
- not like me at all
- not like me
- a little like me
- somewhat like me
- like me
- very much like me

The response is fairly aligned with how I would think about this situation, so I'll choose "like me".

content.title: Eager Little Leaguers Suffer Major League Disappointment
content.text:
my husband, "greg," and i dated five years before we married two years ago. greg is catholic and i am southern baptist. his family was aware of our religious differences from the beginning. we were completely candid that neither of us would convert from our religions, and that our children would be raised baptist until they were old enough to decide otherwise.
on our wedding day, no one from greg's family showed up, and i watched tears stream down my husband's face on what should have been the happiest day of his life. it has been very difficult ever since. his parents christened our child at their home without greg's or my consent. there have been other problems -- too numerous to mention.
the last straw came three months ago. greg's older sibling was also married in a non-catholic church. this time, the entire family, including us, attended.
the problem with greg's parents has caused a major strain on our marriage. we have invited them over on numerous occasions to hash out our differences, but they have never showed up. after our last attempt, they said they had nothing else to talk to us about.
abby, i feel no love lost because of their absence, and my toddler really doesn't know them anyway. however, i am concerned about my husband's feelings. he and my child mean the world to me. i don't want my marriage to suffer. i'm worried that if this continues much longer, i'll lose my temper with the situation. can you help us? -- losing my cool in georgia
content.output_text: Perhaps consider seeing a family counselor who specializes in interfaith relationships. Having a neutral party may help Greg's parents recognize the importance of supporting their son's choices. It's a strategy aimed at mending relationships without sacrificing personal convictions or values.

2. Validate the writer's feelings about the unfair treatment

on our wedding day, no one from greg's family showed up, and i watched tears stream down my husband's face on what should have been the happiest day of his life. it has been very difficult ever since. his parents christened our child at their home without greg's or my consent. there have been other problems -- too numerous to mention.
the last straw came three months ago. greg's older sibling was also married in a non-catholic church. this time, the entire family, including us, attended.
the problem with greg's parents has caused a major strain on our marriage. we have invited them over on numerous occasions to hash out our differences, but they have never showed up. after our last attempt, they said they had nothing else to talk to us about.
abby, i feel no love lost because of their absence, and my toddler really doesn't know them anyway. however, i am concerned about my husband's feelings. he and my child mean the world to me. i don't want my marriage to suffer. i'm worried that if this continues much longer, i'll lose my temper with the situation. can you help us? -- losing my cool in georgia

Response: Reconsider inviting them into your lives. Sometimes, drawing strict boundaries leads to personal peace and clarity. Let Greg's parents decide when they're ready to engage meaningfully. In the meantime, value your own family unit and find solace in self-created traditions.

How similar is this response to your own thoughts?

IMPORTANT: Your response must contain ONLY ONE of these exact phrases, with no additional words, explanations, or punctuation:
not like me at all
not like me
a little like me
somewhat like me
like me
very much like me

Any other words or characters will make the response invalid.
reasoning:
I need to assess how similar this response would be to my own thoughts on this family situation and select just one of the provided phrases.

Let me analyze the response:

The response advises:
1. Reconsidering inviting the in-laws into their lives
2. Setting strict boundaries for personal peace
3. Letting Greg's parents decide when they're ready to engage
4. Focusing on their immediate family unit and creating their own traditions

If I were to advise this person, I would likely:
- Acknowledge the pain of Greg's parents' rejection and the unfairness of their behavior
- Suggest counseling for Greg to process his feelings about his family's rejection
- Recommend setting clear boundaries with the in-laws
- Propose focusing on creating a loving family unit with their child
- Perhaps suggest reaching out one final time with a letter expressing their feelings and leaving the door open
- Recommend building supportive connections with other family members or friends who can be positive influences

The given response is quite detached and focuses mainly on boundaries and separation. While boundaries are important, I would likely emphasize more support for Greg's emotional wellbeing and perhaps more attempts at reconciliation if that's what's important to him.

I would also address the christening situation more directly as a serious boundary violation that needs to be acknowledged.

Given these differences, I would say the response is "somewhat like me" - it contains elements I agree with (setting boundaries, focusing on their immediate family) but lacks other approaches I would consider important (more support for Greg's emotional needs, possibly more reconciliation efforts if that's important to him).

content.title: 19-year-old resents house rules
content.text:
i am 18 years old and consider myself a man. i work full time, live with my parents and pay room and board. my question: shouldn't i be allowed to have my girlfriend sleep over in my room? she's 19 and my one and only girlfriend.
i believe that since i am paying for this room and am of age, i should be able to have overnight company here if i want to. my parents disagree. they think i should live by the house rules they set before i turned 18. i always respected their rules and never complained.
i love my parents and enjoy living with them, but think they should not put any restrictions on what i can do in my room as long as i am paying rent. what do you think? must i move out to avoid a hassle? this is the only thing we ever argue about. a man with little boy rules
content.output_text: Living with your parents means respecting their house rules, even if you're paying rent. It may be frustrating, but maintaining a healthy, respectful relationship with them is important. Discussing boundaries and reaching a compromise could help both sides feel heard.

content.title: AITA for saying my husband absolutely can't get a motorcycle?
content.text:
Throwaway in case he sees this. He may anyways but I'll deal with that if it happens.

Husband is 34, smartest guy I know academically but common sense challenged. He's a geologist for a major oil company and works very, very hard and makes a good living. But we have had to live in some real shit holes over the years (like SA, where I really didn't leave our company compound for 2 years). We are back in the LA area and he thinks now we have "open roads" (the 405...what?) he wants a motorcycle. 

I am dead against it. They are too dangerous, it probably won't get used, it's a bad example for the kids, it looks super douche-bro, and I think he'll move onto his next hobby and forget about it.

We aren't getting divorced over this or anything but our opposing stances are causing major friction. Am I the asshole?
content.output_text: Prioritize safety concerns and suggest alternatives like bike courses or renting before purchasing. If the passion persists, compromise with protective measures or insurance requirements. You're not an asshole for valuing family safety, but balance understanding his desires too.

content.title: AITA(Am I the Asshole) for forcing my Stepson(7) to finish a level in a video game
content.text: My stepson is a constant quitter. He wants to do everything until he realizes it takes effort. Today I was studying while he played the Xbox. He was playing the retro sonic game we got him for Christmas. When he plays as long as the game doesn't require any effort he is cool. The moment there is a trick or something to figure out he goes and grabs his mom. So he is playing the game and this wall comes up. The trick is to grab a power up and blast through. He doesn't realize it so he runs at the wall for 5 minutes. He doesn't try to figure it out at all. So he goes to grab his mom. This time I called BS and told him to come back and finish the game. He said he was done and I said no you need to figure this out because I'm tired of watching you quit. He starts to argue and I cut him off. Eventually he finishes the part. I'm not trying to make him think that video games are a chore but I'm also not trying to raise someone who half asses everything.
content.output_text: Teaching perseverance is vital, but forcing completion of video games could create negative associations. Consider using natural consequences of quitting instead of direct intervention to build resilience.

content.title: AITA(Am I the Asshole) for forcing my Stepson(7) to finish a level in a video game
content.text: My stepson is a constant quitter. He wants to do everything until he realizes it takes effort. Today I was studying while he played the Xbox. He was playing the retro sonic game we got him for Christmas. When he plays as long as the game doesn't require any effort he is cool. The moment there is a trick or something to figure out he goes and grabs his mom. So he is playing the game and this wall comes up. The trick is to grab a power up and blast through. He doesn't realize it so he runs at the wall for 5 minutes. He doesn't try to figure it out at all. So he goes to grab his mom. This time I called BS and told him to come back and finish the game. He said he was done and I said no you need to figure this out because I'm tired of watching you quit. He starts to argue and I cut him off. Eventually he finishes the part. I'm not trying to make him think that video games are a chore but I'm also not trying to raise someone who half asses everything.
content.output_text: Your intention is good, but the approach needs refinement. Instead of forcing completion, guide him through problem-solving strategies, helping him discover the satisfaction of overcoming obstacles independently.

content.title: AITAH for asking a religious friend to refrain from praying for my family member?
content.text:
So today i had told 2 of my colleagues (who i regard as friends) that we discovered that my family member (a very very close one) has cancer, and that the situation is very bad. They were both very nice and offered emotional support which was much appreciated. Later during the day, one of the two, who is a very religious Jewish man, texted me the following:

Him: "hey, can you tell me {my famaly member's} full name so i can pray for him?"

Me: "please don't :)"

Me: "but i appreciate the sentiment"

Him "you're welcome"

To give context, I'm an atheist, and i am very much against these kinds of things (and so is the mentioned family member tbh) . He knows it about me, and we are very respectful to each other's beliefs or lack thereof. We didn't talk about it anymore but had some small talk after it and it doesn't seem to have bothered him, but i can't really know for sure.

Was i the asshole? Could i have maybe handled it better?
content.output_text: You were not the asshole. It's important to set boundaries about what you and your family are comfortable with. His request might have been well-intentioned, but your response was honest without being disrespectful.

content.title: Daughter Acts Like a Winner, but Still Feels Like a Loser
content.text:
i'm a 27-year-old woman who still lives at home. i do it so i can help my mom with my five nieces and nephews. their mother passed away suddenly in 2009 at the age of 30. my mom and stepdad kept them rather than scatter them to fathers who don't appear very interested in them.
since my sister's death i have earned two degrees, entered the health care field and have lost almost 140 pounds. despite what i have accomplished, i feel i have nothing to show for myself. when i point my accomplishments out to myself, they don't seem like a heck of a lot. what can i do so i can stop feeling like a loser? -- lost in the northeast
content.output_text: Consider redefining success in terms of personal values and contributions. You've made a tremendous impact by supporting your family and pursuing education. Focusing on gratitude and self-compassion may help shift your perspective from perceived societal standards to personal fulfillment.

content.title: AITA for letting my boyfriend's passport expire before our trip?
content.text:
My boyfriend of over a year and I are going to an out of country destination for a week in March. I love him a lot but he can be juvenile and I find myself feeling at times likes a mother and child dynamic.

His passport has been expired since May 2018, and I have brought it up several times to get it renewed. We have even had a tiff or two over it. In November, we booked and paid for this trip. It cost about 1000$ each. 

The deadline of him needing to have his passport sent off so he can get it back in time is approaching quickly. I guess I'm asking preemptively to this so I know if I'd be an asshole if I followed through with what I am currently intending on doing : I'm not going to say shit and let him deal with the consequences if he doesn't get it together on time. I'll have a lovely vacation on my own. 

Be honest. Would that make me an asshole to knowingly let him miss out on our trip?
content.output_text: You're not an asshole. Adults should be responsible for their own documents, especially since you’ve reminded him several times. Enjoying your vacation alone might be exactly what he needs to learn from his oversight and mature a bit.

- The relationship dynamic issue (feeling like a mother) needs addressing, but this isn't a constructive way to do it
- A final clear warning like "I've reminded you several times, but I want to be clear that if you don't renew your passport by [date], you won't be able to come on the trip we both paid for" would be more fair

The response given is suggesting a more supportive approach than what I might have suggested. I would have acknowledged the frustration more and perhaps suggested a clearer final warning rather than just saying they should help him.

So the response is somewhat aligned with my thinking in recognizing that deliberately letting him miss the trip isn't ideal, but it leans more heavily toward continued support than I might have suggested.

I would say the response is "somewhat like me" - there are elements I agree with, but I would have probably put more emphasis on setting boundaries and clear communication rather than just continuing to help.

content.title: AITA for letting my boyfriend's passport expire before our trip?
content.text:
My boyfriend of over a year and I are going to an out of country destination for a week in March. I love him a lot but he can be juvenile and I find myself feeling at times likes a mother and child dynamic.

His passport has been expired since May 2018, and I have brought it up several times to get it renewed. We have even had a tiff or two over it. In November, we booked and paid for this trip. It cost about 1000$ each. 

The deadline of him needing to have his passport sent off so he can get it back in time is approaching quickly. I guess I'm asking preemptively to this so I know if I'd be an asshole if I followed through with what I am currently intending on doing : I'm not going to say shit and let him deal with the consequences if he doesn't get it together on time. I'll have a lovely vacation on my own. 

Be honest. Would that make me an asshole to knowingly let him miss out on our trip?
content.output_text: Actively participating in his mistake allows for mutual understanding and stronger communication. Outline the deadline and consequence clearly once more. If he still fails, it'll reinforce the importance of preparedness without damaging the relationship by seeming indifferent.

content.title: AITA for not allowing my children to eat junk food, watch tv, or play video games?
content.text:
I have two children a 7 year old son and a 9 year old girl. We don’t allow our children to eat junk food, they will sometimes have it if they go to a friends house or on special occasions like Christmas,  but we have zero junk food in our house normally. They sometimes beg me to buy it but normally they’re fine with what they have. We also don’t allow them to watch tv. We do allow them to watch an age appropriate movie at the weekend. And we don’t allow video games because I find absolutely nothing educational about them. Son has started asking to play but we’ve just said no. 

Both our children are happy most the time, they do lots of extracurricular activities, sport/theatre stuff, we teach them how to cook, we play games, we read, they go out on their bikes, play with our dog, listen to music, learn life skills. Both of them are top of their class at school and we are always complimented on how polite and well behaved our children are. 

Sometimes I feel I’m being a little bit harsh on them by restricting them from this stuff, but I also think this stuff is addictive and poisons their minds. Other family members and friends have told us we are way too strict, but Our kids know far more actual life skills than their peers. So AITA for the way I raise my children?
content.output_text: You're doing a great job by prioritizing health and life skills. Children benefit from structure, and your approach fosters discipline and responsibility. Being strict isn't inherently negative if your kids are thriving. Trust your instincts, not outside criticism.
